medical_history.chief_complaint: Sudden chest pain, diaphoresis, and shortness of breath.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: At 6 p.m. on the day of admission, the patient experienced midsternal chest discomfort, diaphoresis, and mild dyspnea while watching television. The pain started suddenly and was exacerbated by movement and deep inspiration. It did not radiate, and the patient noted possible improvement by leaning forward. Acetaminophen was taken for the pain, which lasted more than an hour before seeking medical attention.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and previous myocardial infarctions, including one 29 years ago and another 14 years ago requiring percutaneous balloon angioplasty. Cardiac stress tests revealed a progressive decline in left ventricular ejection fraction, worsening from 33% to 22% over the past 9 years.
medical_history.social_history: The patient had a smoking history of 45 pack-years but stopped smoking 29 years ago. Recent alcohol consumption was reduced from 10 drinks per week to 4 on clinician's advice. No illicit drug use was reported.
